Played CoH3 on my Xbox before switching to PC a year ago and it felt like absolute unfinished modern slop, this game is much better to play in basically everyway so far: 
-Combat feel, attention to detail with units, map design, and just the overall aesthetic of the game as well as general design choices feel much better than CoH3 (Ostfront > Italian Front all day). 
-It has a well established modding scene; Wikingr, Spearhead, Eichenlaub, AllUnits mod etc. A few of the mods I mentioned are a complete overhaul of game mechanics and unit roster. Better yet, they make the AI much more competitive to play against. Aggressive, good use of their unit comps and proper usage of their commander call ins. This is great as the intelligence of the Vanilla AI is arguably the only thing CoH2 lacks compared to CoH3. 
-The game still has a fairly active multiplayer scene for it's age but of course most of them will crush a newbies so your mileage will vary. 
-Yes the game has alot of DLC, as does CoH3... The in game supply system allows you to earn new Commanders/Doctrines, intel bulletins (stat modifiers such as increased accuracy for a specific unit type), skins and etc just by playing. I got the complete edition of the game with all DLCs and bundles for less than 40$, and I'm sure you could find keys for even cheaper.
-Last but not least no retarded woke campaign or modern goyslop feel like I got from playing CoH3.

First playthrough review time.

I got this game for free, and it is a real-time strategy game set on the Eastern Front of the Second World War. In this type of game, players control their army and make decisions while the battle happens at the same time, instead of waiting for each side to play one after the other. The game shows big battles, changing battle lines, and the push to control more territory. Players need to capture and connect key areas on the map, as these provide the resources needed to build and strengthen their army. Buildings, cover, and unit upgrades all affect how fights unfold, making each battle feel different depending on which areas are held.

This game includes two main campaigns, the Soviet campaign and the US campaign as well as additional scenario based missions through the Theater of War DLCs. The game also includes features that make careful planning important. Units can only see so far, so moving without thinking can be dangerous. Weather plays a big role too, with deep snow, cold, and weak ice affecting how soldiers and vehicles move. Additional missions give players more battles from both sides of the war, showing different situations and challenges.

Overall, the game gives a detailed and challenging look at fighting on the Eastern Front. Players need to make steady decisions, pay attention to the environment, and control their territory carefully. All of these elements work together to create a strategy game where planning, movement, and resource use are very important.

Best ever strategy game even better than its successor company of heroes 3

Company of Heroes 2 is a real-time strategy game developed by Relic Entertainment and released as the sequel to the original Company of Heroes. It focuses on the Eastern Front of World War II, depicting the conflict between the Soviet Red Army and Nazi Germany.

Gameplay emphasizes tactical control of small squads rather than large armies. Players must use cover, flanking, and combined-arms tactics to succeed. The terrain and weather play crucial roles‚Äîdeep snow, ice, and blizzards affect visibility, mobility, and survival, forcing adaptation to harsh battlefield conditions.

The campaign follows the Soviet perspective through a series of missions that mix scripted objectives with dynamic combat. It blends historical realism with a dramatized narrative about duty, sacrifice, and the brutality of war. Alternate game modes, including skirmish and multiplayer, extend replay value with varied maps and strategies.

Combat is visceral and punishing. Every unit matters, and poor positioning can quickly lead to losses. Cover systems, suppression mechanics, and destructible environments make engagements dynamic and unpredictable. Victory relies on resource control and maintaining front-line pressure.

Visually, the game uses the Essence 3.0 engine, featuring realistic lighting, particle effects, and environmental destruction. Snow, fire, and debris react dynamically, contributing to immersion and strategic variability.

Sound design is exceptional. Explosions, weapon fire, and soldier dialogue are impactful and situationally aware. The orchestral soundtrack and multilingual voice acting reinforce the grim, authentic tone of the Eastern Front setting.

Overall, Company of Heroes 2 refines the tactical formula of its predecessor with harsher environments, improved visuals, and demanding strategy. It remains one of the most polished and intense WWII real-time strategy games, rewarding players who value precision, planning, and adaptability.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour ‚Äì 500 g
Water ‚Äì 200 ml
Egg ‚Äì 1
Salt ‚Äì 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes ‚Äì 1 kg
Onions ‚Äì 2
Lard or butter ‚Äì 50 g
Salt ‚Äì to taste
Ground black pepper ‚Äì to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Saut√© the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the saut√©ed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or saut√©ed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

Needs no introduction, a considerable package in an alternate strategy-game style of resource management that scratches a unique itch for most. However, the 64-bit update released a few years back annihilated my performance (on modern specs, mind you!) and I expect not to return in favour of its predecessor CoH 1.

It's an extremely frustrating game and a genuine waste of time. The AI has the worst pathfinding I've ever seen in a game, and to make things even worse there's collisions between vehicles to the point you have waves of tanks and even soldiers frozen in place because they can't move. The AI is a blatant cheater, with a certain double standard when enemy tanks can mow down your soldiers like a hot knife on butter but your own tanks will take forever to take down enemy soldiers. 

The game also crashes frequently, and there's also desyncronization problems that really cause hours of your life to be lost. 

Basically, it's not worth it. In some ways, even Age of Empires 2 is better than this.

It's an extremely frustrating game and a genuine waste of time. The AI has the worst pathfinding I've ever seen in a game, and to make things even worse there's collisions between vehicles to the point you have waves of tanks and even soldiers frozen in place because they can't move. The AI is a blatant cheater, with a certain double standard when enemy tanks can mow down your soldiers like a hot knife on butter but your own tanks will take forever to take down enemy soldiers. 

The game also crashes frequently, and there's also desyncronization problems that really cause hours of your life to be lost. 

Basically, it's not worth it. In some ways, even Age of Empires 2 is better than this.
